questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has also had a 5 kg (11-lb) weight loss. She has a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis. She is sexually active with her husband only. She does not smoke. She drinks one glass of wine per day. She does not use illicit drugs. Her only medication is levothyroxine. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant with no rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a serum alanine aminotransferase level of 990 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase level of 850 U/L, and serum total bilirubin level of 1.1 mg/dL. Liver biopsy shows plasma cell infiltration and areas of periportal piecemeal necrosis. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although not specific, the presence of an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) in this patient would be suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). While her symptoms could also be seen with HCC, she has no risk factors (chronic hepatitis virus infection, chronic alcohol use, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease) and her biopsy results are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of serum antismooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) has a specificity of 80% for the diagnosis of type 1 AIH. Additional laboratory abnormalities in AIH often include positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and increased serum IgG. AIH is also associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as Hashimoto thyroiditis.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) is classically associated with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC). While this patient's symptoms and biopsy results could also be seen with PBC, she lacks the symptoms and findings of a cholestatic process (e.g., pruritus) that are typical for PBC.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of a decreased serum ceruloplasmin concentration in this patient would be suggestive of Wilson disease. While her symptoms could also be seen with Wilson disease, she lacks additional findings to support this diagnosis (e.g., neurologic symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings). Liver histology may also show necrosis, as seen in this patient, but the use of copper staining would show elevated hepatic copper content.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen suggests acute or chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with HBV infection, she has no risk factors for HBV infection (e.g., IV drug use, multiple sexual partners).

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of an elevated transferrin saturation in this patient would be suggestive of hemochromatosis; a transferrin saturation > 50% is ∼ 90% specific for this diagnosis. While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with hemochromatosis, she lacks additional findings to support this diagnosis (hyperpigmented skin, diabetes, arthralgias) and liver histology in hemochromatosis would most often show pronounced siderosis with iron deposits in hepatocytes.

G) INCORRECT:

The presence of positive perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) is associated with several autoimmune conditions and in this clinical context would be suggestive of a diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with PSC, she lacks the symptoms and findings of a cholestatic process (e.g., pruritus) that are typical for PSC. Additionally, liver biopsy in PSC usually would demonstrate inflammation of the biliary duct epithelium, with the eventual development of portal and periportal fibrosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Antihepatitis C virus antibodies are found in individuals who have been exposed to hepatitis C virus (HCV). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with HCV infection, she has no risk factors (e.g., IV drug use, multiple sexual partners).
questions.hint: This patient's age, lack of other risk factors, and biopsy results are highly suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH).

questions.text:
A 42-year-old previously healthy woman presents for evaluation of fatigue, nausea, and painless jaundice for the past 2 weeks. Her only medication is a low-dose oral contraceptive pill. She does not take any other over-the-counter medications or supplements. She has no family history of liver disease. She drinks three glasses of wine per week. She has no history of intravenous drug use.
Her blood pressure is 105/50 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. The sclerae are icteric. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no hepatosplenomegaly, and asterixis is absent.
On initial laboratory testing, the international normalized ratio is 1.1, and other results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
2018
0–35



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
1755
0–35



Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
440
30–120



Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
13.0
0.3–1.0



Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
7.8
0.1–0.3


Albumin (g/dL)
3.4
3.5–5.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7700
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
41
36–46


Platelet count
350,000
150,000–300,000


Additional laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hepatitis C virus antibody
Negative
—


Hepatitis C virus RNA
Undetectable
—


Hepatitis B virus surface antigen
Negative
—


Hepatitis B virus core antibody
Positive
—


Hepatitis B virus surface antibody
Positive
—


Hepatitis A immunoglobulin M
Negative
—



Immunoglobulin G (mg/dL)
1549
614–1295


Antinuclear antibody
1:320
Negative at 1:40 dilution


Anti-smooth-muscle antibody
1:80
Negative at 1:20 dilution


Iron studies




Iron (μg/dL)
90
50–150


Total iron-binding capacity (μg/dL)
300
250–370


Ferritin (ng/mL)
500
10–200


Abdominal ultrasonography shows no biliary ductal dilation and no ascites.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient’s positive tests for core and surface antibodies suggest prior infection with hepatitis B virus, not acute infection.

B) CORRECT:

The potential causes of alanine and aspartate aminotransferase levels greater than 15 times the upper limit of normal are limited and include acute viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis, Wilson disease, ischemic hepatitis, medications or toxins, acute bile-duct obstruction, and the Budd-Chiari syndrome.

This patient’s presentation of painless jaundice and nonspecific symptoms in the setting of elevated immunoglobulin G, antinuclear antibody, and anti-smooth-muscle antibody levels is consistent with autoimmune hepatitis.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of profoundly elevated liver aminotransferase levels in a patient with a hepatocellular pattern of liver injury, a normal abdominal ultrasound, and elevated levels of antinuclear and anti-smooth-muscle antibodies is autoimmune hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis does not lead to extreme elevations in aminotransferase levels.

D) INCORRECT:

She does not have right upper quadrant pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites that are the typical presenting features of the Budd-Chiari syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis (previously referred to as primary biliary cirrhosis) is not associated with extremely elevated liver-enzyme levels and is usually associated with elevations of alkaline phosphatase only.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents with a two-week history of fatigue, dark urine, and generalized pruritus. She reports intermittent right upper quadrant discomfort and joint pains affecting her wrists and knees for the past few months. She has no known medication use or recent travel. On examination, she is jaundiced but has no skin rashes. Tests for viral hepatitis including hepatitis A, B, and C are negative. Antinuclear antibody and anti–smooth muscle antibody results are pending (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Alanine aminotransferase
480 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
520 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Total bilirubin
25 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease may present with liver enzyme abnormalities in young patients, but it is often accompanied by neuropsychiatric symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are absent here. The presentation of pruritus, dark urine, and joint pains suggests an autoimmune or cholestatic process rather than a copper metabolism disorder. The laboratory evaluation lacks copper or ceruloplasmin levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis typically presents with a cholestatic pattern of liver injury, characterized by elevated alkaline phosphatase levels rather than the marked transaminase elevation seen here. It commonly affects middle-aged women and is associated with antimitochondrial antibodies, not antinuclear or anti–smooth muscle antibodies. The patient's age and laboratory findings do not support this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis is associated with metabolic syndrome, including obesity and insulin resistance, which are not present in this patient. The severe transaminase elevation and symptoms such as pruritus, jaundice, and joint pains suggest an inflammatory process of autoimmune or cholestatic origin, not nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. The focus on autoimmune markers further indicates a different etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis manifests in young women with symptoms such as fatigue, dark urine, pruritus, and right upper quadrant discomfort. The laboratory findings of significantly elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels indicate a hepatocellular pattern of liver injury. The absence of viral hepatitis markers suggests a non-infectious etiology, raising suspicion for an autoimmune process. Positive antinuclear antibody and anti–smooth muscle antibody tests would support this diagnosis, indicating an immune-mediated attack on hepatic cells. Joint pain is a common systemic manifestation associated with autoimmune hepatitis, further aligning with this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Autoimmune hepatitis should be considered in young patients with elevated transaminases, jaundice, and extrahepatic symptoms such as arthralgia, especially when viral hepatitis is ruled out.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of fatigue, mild right upper quadrant discomfort, and dark urine. She has hypothyroidism managed with levothyroxine and no other chronic medical conditions. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing shows significantly elevated transaminases, total serum IgG of 25 g/L (reference range 7–16 g/L), and a positive antinuclear antibody test. Her INR is 1.3 (reference range 0.9–1.2), and serum bilirubin is normal (see report).
Liver biopsy: Interface hepatitis with a prominent plasma cell infiltrate
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used in conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome and immune thrombocytopenia. However, in autoimmune hepatitis, characterized by T-cell–mediated liver injury, IVIG does not effectively suppress the inflammatory cascade. Corticosteroids are preferred for their broad immunosuppressive effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined interferon and ribavirin is used for chronic hepatitis C, targeting viral replication. This patient's presentation, with elevated transaminases, increased serum IgG, positive antinuclear antibodies, and plasma cell-rich interface hepatitis, indicates autoimmune hepatitis, not viral infection. Interferon can exacerbate autoimmune conditions and is contraindicated here.

C) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in cholestatic liver diseases like primary biliary cholangitis, characterized by elevated alkaline phosphatase and antimitochondrial antibodies. This patient has elevated transaminases, increased serum IgG, and plasma cell-rich interface hepatitis, indicating autoimmune hepatitis, not a cholestatic process.

D) CORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis is characterized by immune-mediated hepatocyte destruction, presenting with fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, elevated transaminases, and hypergammaglobulinemia, particularly increased serum IgG. Positive antinuclear antibodies and liver biopsy findings of interface hepatitis with plasma cell infiltrate support the diagnosis. High-dose oral prednisolone is the first-line treatment, as corticosteroids reduce hepatic inflammation by suppressing the immune response, decreasing cytokine production, and lymphocyte activity. Early immunosuppressive therapy is crucial to prevent progression to fibrosis or cirrhosis and improve outcomes.

Key learning point: In autoimmune hepatitis, characterized by interface hepatitis with plasma cells on biopsy and elevated ANA, the first-line treatment is immunosuppression with corticosteroids such as prednisolone.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ED with a 2-week history of fatigue, nausea, and upper abdominal pain. She has a medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus. She has no history of alcohol use or hepatotoxic medications. Physical examination reveals mild jaundice. Laboratory studies show ALT 485 U/L, AST 380 U/L, total bilirubin 4.2 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 95 U/L, and elevated IgG. Hepatitis A, B, and C serologies are negative. Which autoantibody combination would most strongly support the diagnosis of type 1 autoimmune hepatitis?

choices.text: Anti-liver-kidney microsomal-1 (anti-LKM-1) antibodies and anti-liver cytosol-1 (ALC-1) antibodies
Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA)
Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) and antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA)
Anti-liver-kidney microsomal-1 (anti-LKM-1) antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-LKM-1 and ALC-1 antibodies are characteristic of type 2 autoimmune hepatitis, not type 1. Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis represents a minority of cases and has distinct serological patterns from type 1 disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are typically associated with primary biliary cholangitis, not autoimmune hepatitis. While AMA can rarely be seen in overlap syndromes, they would not be the primary markers for classic autoimmune hepatitis diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) is highly specific for type 1 autoimmune hepatitis, which accounts for 80% of autoimmune hepatitis cases. This serological pattern, combined with the elevated transaminases, hypergammaglobulinemia, and clinical presentation in a young woman with another autoimmune condition, strongly suggests type 1 autoimmune hepatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

While pANCA may occasionally be present in type 1 autoimmune hepatitis or overlap syndromes, the combination with AMA is not characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis. This combination would suggest possible overlap syndromes but not classic type 1 autoimmune hepatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

This represents a combination of antibodies from both type 1 (ASMA) and type 2 (anti-LKM-1) autoimmune hepatitis classifications. These antibody types are not typically found together as they define separate categories of the disease.
